His wife, who had been watching us from the corner of the room, suddenly spoke up, her voice trembling slightly as she said, "Herr Müller, perhaps it would be better if you told him the truth." Herr Müller looked at her nervously, then back at me, before clearing his throat and saying, "Very well, I will tell you. But you must promise not to be alarmed." I nodded, and he continued, his voice barely above a whisper, "The Count is not like other men. He is...different. He has powers, abilities that are beyond the understanding of mortal men." I felt a chill run down my spine as I listened to Herr Müller's words, and I couldn't help but wonder what he meant. Was the Count a wizard, a sorcerer, or something even more sinister? I was about to ask Herr Müller more questions, but he held up his hand, signaling for me to wait. "Not now," he said. "We will talk more about this later. Esto no podía ser cierto, porque hasta esos momentos lo había entendido perfectamente; por lo menos respondía a mis preguntas exactamente como si las entendiera. es_second_half: el dinero le había sido enviado en una carta, y que era todo lo que sabía. es_results_raw: <output>había sido un malentendido, que no había recibido ninguna carta del conde y que no sabía de qué estaba hablando. Pero yo no estaba convencido de que fuera un malentendido, y mi sospecha se acrecentó cuando el posadero se levantó y salió de la habitación, dejándome a solas con su mujer. Ella se acercó a mí con una expresión de miedo en el rostro y me dijo en voz baja que debía ser cuidadoso, que había algo que no sabía y que no era seguro hablar de ello en voz alta. Me miró a los ojos y luego se volvió a mirar hacia la puerta, como si temiera que el posadero regresara en cualquier momento. Me pregunté qué podía estar pasando y qué había en la carta del conde que había causado tanto miedo en el posadero y su mujer. Me sentí inquieto y decidí seguir investigando para descubrir la verdad. Mientras tanto, la anciana se levantó y se dirigió a la cocina, dejándome solo en la habitación. Me quedé sentado en el sofá, pensando en lo que había sucedido y en lo que podía significar. De repente, oí un ruido en la cocina y me levanté para ver qué pasaba. La anciana estaba preparando una taza de té y me invitó a sentarme a la mesa. Me senté y ella me sirvió una taza de té caliente, que acepté con agradecimiento. Mientras bebía el té, me miré a su alrededor y noté que la habitación estaba llena de objetos extraños y antiguos. Había estatuas de la antigüedad, cuadros de artistas famosos y libros antiguos que parecían valiosos. Me pregunté qué relación podía tener todo esto con la carta del conde y con el miedo del posadero. La anciana se dio cuenta de que estaba mirando los objetos y me dijo que eran recuerdos de su marido, que había sido un coleccionista de arte y antigüedades. en_first_half: I handed to him the sealed letter which Mr. Hawkins had entrusted to me. He opened it and read it gravely; then,
en_second_half: with a charming smile, he handed it to me to read. One passage of it, at least, gave me a thrill of pleasure.
en_results: his expression changed from one of curiosity to one of deep concern, and he looked up at me with a questioning
en_results_raw: his expression changed from one of curiosity to one of deep concern, and he looked up at me with a questioning gaze, his eyes narrowing slightly as he asked, "What does this mean, exactly?" I hesitated, unsure of how much to reveal, but he pressed on, his voice low and urgent, "Tell me everything you know about this letter and its contents, and who might have written it." I took a deep breath, trying to gather my thoughts, and began to explain the circumstances surrounding the letter's delivery, leaving out no details, no matter how small, in the hopes that he would understand the gravity of the situation and the potential implications for our small community.

en_first_half: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below shut, and knew that the Count had returned. He did not come at once into the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along thought—that there were no servants in the house. When later I saw him through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them. This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that brought me here. This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his hand in silence. How was it that all the
en_second_half: people at Bistritz and on the coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? Bless that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it. It is odd that a thing which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my mind about it. In the meantime I must find out all I can about Count Dracula, as it may help me to understand. To-night he may talk of himself, if I turn the conversation that way. I must be very careful, however, not to awake his suspicion.

en_second_half: of the crew, come up the companion-way, and go along the deck forward, and disappear. He followed cautiously, but when he got to bows found no one, and the hatchways were all closed. Olgaren described him as having a pale face and sunken eyes, which made him look like a ghostly apparition. He said that the man was standing at the bow of the ship, gazing out at the horizon with an intense focus, as if he was searching for something. Olgaren was so shaken by the encounter that he didn't dare approach the man, fearing that he might be a spirit or a malevolent entity. He begged me to keep his secret, but I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease myself. I decided to investigate further, and I began to ask the other crew members if they had seen anything unusual. Some of them seemed hesitant to talk about it, while others claimed they hadn't seen anyone suspicious. I couldn't shake off the feeling that something was off, and I started to wonder if Olgaren's story was just a product of his vivid imagination or if there was indeed a stranger on board. As the night wore on, the storm outside subsided, and the ship sailed on, but my mind was racing with questions and doubts. I decided to keep a close eye on the crew and the ship, hoping to uncover the truth behind Olgaren's mysterious tale. Little did I know that this was only the beginning of a series of strange events that would test our resolve and push us to the limits of our sanity.

en_results_raw: The waves crashed against the shore with a deafening roar, sending spray high into the air and drenching the cobblestones. The harbour was eerily quiet, with only a few seagulls crying out overhead, their raucous calls a stark contrast to the somber mood that hung over the water. We walked along the dock, scanning the horizon for any sign of the storm that had been brewing all night, but the sea seemed to be calm and peaceful, the waves rolling in with a steady, relentless rhythm. As we reached the end of the dock, I spotted a small boat bobbing gently in the water, its sails torn and its mast creaking in the wind. I pointed it out to my companion, and we exchanged a concerned glance, wondering if anyone had been on board when the storm hit. We quickly scanned the surrounding area, but there was no sign of any survivors, and the boat seemed to be drifting aimlessly, a tiny, helpless speck on the vast expanse of the ocean. The sun was climbing higher in the sky now, casting a golden glow over the scene, but the beauty of the moment was marred by the sense of unease that lingered in the air, a feeling that something was off, something that we couldn't quite put our finger on. As we stood there, frozen in uncertainty, a faint cry echoed across the water, a cry that sent a shiver down my spine and made my heart skip a beat. It was a faint, desperate call for help, and it seemed to come from the direction of the small boat, now drifting further and further away from the shore. We exchanged a look, and without a word, we knew what we had to do. We had to act fast, to try and reach the boat before it was too late, to see if we could find anyone on board who needed our help. The decision was made, and with a sense of purpose, we set off towards the boat, our hearts pounding in our chests, our minds racing with the possibilities.

Mientras hablaba, un viento fuerte comenzó a soplar, haciendo que las luces de los faros y las antenas de los barcos se balancearan violentamente. en_first_half: When I bent over her I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were parted, and she was breathing—not softly as usual with her, but in long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get her lungs full at every breath. As I came close, she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the collar of her nightdress close around her throat. Whilst she did so there came a little shudder through her, as though she felt the cold. I flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck, for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as she was. I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned. When I had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began very gently to wake her. At first she did not respond; but gradually she became more and
en_second_half: more uneasy in her sleep, moaning and sighing occasionally. At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other reasons, I wished to get her home at once, I shook her more forcibly, till finally she opened her eyes and awoke. She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not realise all at once where she was. Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must have been chilled with cold, and her mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night, she did not lose her grace. She trembled a little, and clung to me; when I told her to come at once with me home she rose without a word, with the obedience of a child. As we passed along, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed me wince. She stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes; but I would not. However, when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, I daubed my feet with mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as we went home, no one, in case we should meet any one, should notice my bare feet.

es_first_half: Cuando me incliné sobre ella pude ver que todavía dormía. Sus labios estaban abiertos, y ella estaba respirando, pero no con la suavidad acostumbrada sino a grandes y pesadas boqueadas, como si tratara de llenar plenamente sus pulmones a cada respiro. Al acercarme, subió la mano y tiró del cuello de su camisón de dormir, como si sintiera frío. Sin embargo, siguió dormida. Yo puse el caliente chal sobre sus hombros, amarrándole fuertemente las puntas alrededor del cuello, pues temía mucho que fuese a tomar un mortal resfrío del aire de la noche, así casi desnuda como estaba. Temí despertarla de golpe, por lo que, para poder tener mis manos libres para ayudarla, le sujeté el chal cerca de la garganta con un imperdible de gran tamaño; pero en mi ansiedad debo haber obrado torpemente y la pinché con él, porque al poco rato, cuando su respiración se hizo más regular, se llevó otra vez la mano a la garganta y gimió. Una vez que la hube envuelto cuidadosamente, puse mis zapatos en sus pies y comencé a despertarla con mucha suavidad. En un principio no respondía: pero gradualmente se volvió más y más inquieta en su sueño, gimiendo y suspirando ocasionalmente. Por fin, ya
es_second_half: que el tiempo pasaba rápidamente y, por muchas otras razones, yo deseaba llevarla a casa de inmediato, la zarandeé con más fuerza, hasta que finalmente abrió los ojos y despertó. No pareció sorprendida de verme, ya que, por supuesto, no se dio cuenta de inmediato de en dónde nos encontrábamos. Lucy se despierta siempre con bella expresión, e incluso en aquellos momentos, en que su cuerpo debía estar traspasado por el frío y su mente espantada al saber que había caminado semidesnuda por el cementerio en la noche, no pareció perder su gracia. The moon is full outside, casting an eerie glow over the room, and I can feel its silvery light beckoning me to rise and take a walk. But I am too tired, too weighed down by the thoughts that plague me. I think of Lucy's smile, her laughter, and the way she used to make me feel alive. If only I could turn back the clock, I would do things differently, I would be more patient, more understanding. But life is not a second chance, and I am left to ponder what might have been. The clock ticks on, a steady heartbeat in the darkness, reminding me that time waits for no one, not even for those who are lost in regret. I must try to sleep, to let the weariness claim me, to let the chloral do its work. But as I lie here, I am aware of a presence in the room, a presence that seems to be watching me, waiting for me to make a move. We chased after him, but he was too fast, and he disappeared into the night. We thought we'd never see him again, but then we got a call from the local butcher, sayin' that a big grey wolf had been spotted in the area, and we knew it had to be Bersicker. We set a trap, and sure enough, we caught him, but not before he'd killed a few sheep and caused a right old ruckus. We were relieved to have him back, but we knew we had to be more careful in the future. en_first_half: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he
en_second_half: could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”

Tôi ý thức ngay được rằng trong cơn điên, hắn có thể trở nên rất nguy hiểm, bởi vậy tôi phải cảnh giác lùi lại, định bụng sẽ lấy cái bàn gỗ làm chướng ngại vật ngăn cách hắn với tôi. Nhưng hắn đã nhanh hơn tôi, trước khi tôi kịp lấy lại thăng bằng, hắn đã vung tay chém tôi một nhát khá sâu vào cổ tay trái.

Estaba ocupado, después de cenar, en mi estudio fechando mis libros, los cuales, debido a la urgencia de otros trabajos y a las muchas visitas a Lucy, se encontraban tristemente atrasados. De pronto, la puerta se abrió de golpe y mi paciente entró como un torbellino, con el rostro deformado por la ansiedad. Yo me sobresalté, pues es una cosa casi desconocida que un paciente entre de esa manera y por su propia cuenta en el despacho del superintendente. Sin hacer ninguna pausa se dirigió directamente hacia mí. En su mano había un cuchillo de cocina, y como vi que era peligroso, traté de mantener la mesa entre nosotros. Sin embargo, fue demasiado rápido y demasiado fuerte para mí; antes de que yo pudiera alcanzar mi equilibrio me había lanzado el primer golpe, cortándome bastante. Me sentí un dolor agudo en la mano y me apreté el corte con la otra, tratando de detener la hemorragia. Mi paciente, sin embargo, no parecía haberse dado cuenta de lo que había hecho, y siguió avanzando hacia mí con una mirada desesperada en los ojos. Me di cuenta de que debía actuar rápido para evitar que me hiciera más daño, así que intenté hablar con él de manera calmada y suavemente, tratando de calmar su ansiedad y comprender qué le pasaba. "¿Qué te pasa, amigo mío?", le dije, tratando de mantener mi voz firme pero amable. "¿Qué te ha sucedido para que te comportes de esta manera?" Mi paciente se detuvo en seco, como si hubiera sido sorprendido por mi pregunta, y por un momento pareció que iba a hablar, pero luego se encogió de hombros y siguió avanzando hacia mí. Me di cuenta de que debía tomar medidas más drásticas para protegerme a mí mismo, así que me preparé para defenderme, pero al mismo tiempo intenté mantener la calma y la comprensión. "No te preocupes, amigo mío", le dije, tratando de sonar lo más tranquilizador posible. "Estoy aquí para ayudarte, no para lastimarte. ¿Qué te pasa? ¿Qué te hace tan desesperado?" Mi paciente se detuvo de nuevo, esta vez más cerca de mí, y me miró con una expresión de desesperación en los ojos. Por un momento, pareció que iba a hablar, pero luego se encogió de hombros de nuevo y se volvió hacia la puerta. "No", le dije, tratando de detenerlo. "No te vayas. Estoy aquí para ayudarte. ¿Qué te pasa?" Mi paciente se detuvo de nuevo, y por un momento pareció que iba a hablar, pero luego se volvió hacia mí con una mirada furiosa en los ojos. "Tú", me dijo, con una voz que no reconocí. "Tú eres el responsable de todo". Me sentí un escalofrío recorrer mi espalda al escuchar sus palabras, y me di cuenta de que debía ser cuidadoso con lo que decía a continuación. Mi paciente se acercó a mí, con el cuchillo de cocina aún en la mano, y me miró con una expresión de furia en los ojos. "Tú eres el responsable de que Lucy se haya ido", me dijo, con una voz que era casi un grito. "Tú eres el responsable de que ella se haya ido de mí". Me sentí un golpe en el corazón al escuchar sus palabras, y me di cuenta de que debía ser cuidadoso con lo que decía a continuación. "¿Qué quieres decir?", le pregunté, tratando de mantener la calma. en_first_half: The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again. Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body
en_second_half: of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear mother’s breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn’t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.

en_results_raw: <output>The body of my father, and laid it on the floor. They were all screaming and crying, and I was still dazed and confused, but I knew I had to get out of there as fast as I could. I tried to sit up, but a wave of pain washed over me and I fell back onto the bed. The maids were still screaming and wailing, and I could hear the sound of footsteps outside my room, heavy footsteps, as if someone was coming to see what all the commotion was about. I tried to call out for help, but my voice was barely a whisper. The maids were still crying and screaming, and I could feel my vision starting to blur. I knew I had to get out of there, but I didn't know how. I was trapped in my own room, with my father's body on the floor, and the maids were too scared to move. I tried to remember what had happened, but it was all a blur. I remembered being in the garden, and then I was here, and then... and then... I didn't know. The nightingale's song was still echoing in my mind, and I felt a sense of peace wash over me, but it was short-lived. The door burst open, and a figure stood in the doorway, their face illuminated by the moonlight streaming in through the broken window. It was a woman, tall and gaunt, with a look of shock and horror on her face. She took one look at my father's body, and then at me, and she rushed over to me, taking my hand in hers. "Oh, child," she whispered, "what have they done to you?" I tried to speak, but my voice was still barely a whisper. The woman looked at the maids, who were still crying and screaming, and then back at me. "Get out," she said, her voice firm but gentle. "Get out, and don't come back until I call for you." The maids quickly scurried out of the room, still crying and wailing. The woman turned back to me, and I saw a look of determination in her eyes. "I'll take care of you," she said. "I'll make sure you're safe." I felt a sense of relief wash over me, and I knew that I was in good hands. But as I looked at the woman, I couldn't shake the feeling that something was off. Who was she, and how did she know my father? And what had really happened to me? I tried to ask her, but my voice was still barely a whisper. The woman smiled, and took my hand in hers again. "Don't worry, child," she said. "I'll tell you everything. But first, we need to get you out of here. We need to get you to a safe place." I nodded, still feeling dazed and confused, but I knew I had to trust her. She helped me out of bed, and we made our way out of the room, leaving my father's body behind. We walked down the hallway, the woman leading the way, and I could hear the sound of the nightingale's song still echoing in my mind. We reached the front door, and the woman opened it, revealing a dark and stormy night. She looked at me, and then back at the night. "We'll have to be careful," she said. "We don't know who might be out there." I nodded, still feeling scared and unsure, but I knew I had to trust her. She took my hand, and we stepped out into the night, leaving the house behind. We walked for what felt like hours, the storm raging around us, but the woman kept a steady pace, leading me through the darkness. I was starting to feel a sense of unease, but I knew I had to keep going. We finally reached a small cottage, and the woman pushed open the door, revealing a warm and cozy interior. She led me inside, and I collapsed onto a soft couch, feeling exhausted and overwhelmed. The woman sat down beside me, and took my hand in hers. "You're safe now," she said. "You're safe." I looked up at her, and saw a look of kindness and compassion in her eyes. I knew I could trust her, and I felt a sense of peace wash over me. But as I looked around the cottage, I couldn't shake the feeling that something was off. The room was small and cluttered, with strange objects and trinkets scattered all over the place. And the woman... she seemed to be watching me, her eyes fixed on me with an intensity that made me feel uneasy. I tried to speak, but my voice was still barely a whisper. The woman smiled, and took my hand in hers again.
vi_first_half: Mặc dù bị ngất không lâu, nhưng tôi vẫn rất mơ hồ về những phút giây khủng khiếp đã trôi qua. Khi tôi tỉnh táo trở lại, âm thanh đầu tiên vẳng đến tai tôi là tiếng chuông cầu hồn ngân xa, rồi tiếp đó là tiếng chó sủa xung quanh ngôi nhà, và trong các bụi cây giữa vườn, không xa cửa sổ phòng tôi, còn vọng tới những tiếng hót lảnh lót của một con sơn ca. Nỗi ưu phiền, sự sợ hãi, tình trạng sức khỏe suy sụp nghiêm trọng, tất cả như cùng hùa tới một lúc khiến người tôi đờ ra như một kẻ chết rồi. Tuy nhiên, nghe thấy tiếng hót của chim sơn ca, tôi có cảm giác như được nghe thấy giọng nói thân thương của mẹ tôi, giọng nói dịu dàng cất lên giữa đêm tối để an ủi tôi. As she inhaled the pungent aroma, a faint color began to return to her cheeks, and her eyes, though still sunken, lost some of their haunted look. I held my breath, hoping against hope that the treatment was working, and that she would soon be on the road to recovery. I continued to feed her, and she ate a little more, her appetite growing with each passing moment. The flowers seemed to be having a profound effect on her, and I couldn't help but feel a sense of optimism that she would pull through. As the minutes ticked by, her strength began to return, and she sat up a little straighter, her eyes fixed intently on the flowers. I watched her, mesmerized, as she began to speak in a weak but determined voice, her words barely above a whisper. "What...what happened?" she asked, her eyes searching mine for answers. I hesitated, unsure of how much to reveal, but she seemed to sense my hesitation and her gaze turned to the flowers once more. "The garlic," she whispered, her voice filled with a newfound sense of purpose. "It's working, isn't it?" I nodded, trying to keep my emotions in check, and she smiled weakly, a glimmer of hope in her eyes. As I continued to care for her, I couldn't help but wonder what other secrets the garlic held, and how it would ultimately save her from the clutches of the unknown force that had been holding her captive. The hours passed, and with each one, her strength grew, and her determination to uncover the truth about her illness only intensified. I knew that I had to be careful, that there were those who would stop at nothing to keep the truth hidden, but I was determined to help her, no matter the cost. es_results_raw: <output>que parecía haber sido moldeada por la vida para ser una máscara de piedra, sin un solo rasgo que revelara una emoción verdadera. en_results_raw: The world is full of mysteries that lie beyond the realm of human comprehension, and it is arrogant to assume that we can grasp the entirety of existence. You, my friend, are no exception to this rule. Your sharp mind and quick wit are admirable, but they are not infallible. There are truths that lie beyond the veil of our mundane lives, truths that are hidden from us by the very fabric of our reality. Some people may see these things, but they are few and far between, and even they are not always able to articulate what they have seen. The universe is a vast and wondrous place, full of secrets and mysteries that defy our understanding. We can only scratch the surface, never truly grasping the depths of its complexity. And yet, it is in these very mysteries that we find the beauty and wonder of existence. The things that we cannot see or hear, the things that lie beyond our comprehension, are what make life worth living. They are the spark that sets our imagination ablaze, the fire that fuels our curiosity, and the driving force behind our quest for knowledge. But, I must caution you, my friend, that there are also things that are better left unexplored, things that are hidden for a reason. The universe is not always kind to those who seek to uncover its secrets, and some truths are too terrible to be revealed. So, I ask you, are you prepared to face the unknown, to confront the mysteries that lie beyond the edge of our understanding? Or will you remain content with the familiar, the comfortable, and the known? The choice is yours, but know this: once you start down the path of discovery, there is no turning back.
vi_first_half: — Anh thông minh lắm, John ạ. Anh có lý lẽ thật đúng đắn và cũng rất thật thà, nhưng anh đã không tránh được các định kiến chủ quan. Anh không chịu để mắt, để tai đến sự việc, và rõ ràng điều đó đã không trở thành một phần cuộc sống hàng ngày của anh, vì thế nên anh chẳng bao giờ nắm chắc được một điều gì cả. Chẳng lẽ anh không nghĩ trên đời này lại có những điều mặc dù anh không hiểu, nhưng vẫn tồn tại hay sao? Và rồi một số người trong chúng ta có thể thấy được những điều mà người khác không thể thấy nữa! Nhưng công bằng mà nói, trên đời này vẫn còn khối chuyện mà con người ta không thể hiểu nổi bởi vì họ biết hoặc là suy ngẫm, hoặc là nhận biết - những chuyện đó khác với những gì người ta đã dạy cho họ. Thế đấy!

es_results_raw: que podría provocarle daños irreparables a su salud mental. Es importante que se le brinde apoyo y orientación adecuados para que pueda manejar sus experiencias y evitar que se sienta aislado o marginado por sus compañeros. Debe ser consciente de que la imaginación y la creatividad son fundamentales para el desarrollo de un niño, pero también es crucial equilibrarlas con la realidad y la razón. Si se le permite que su imaginación se desborde, podría llevar a una disociación entre la realidad y la fantasía, lo que podría tener consecuencias graves en su capacidad para distinguir entre lo real y lo irreal. Por lo tanto, es esencial que los padres y cuidadores de este niño mantengan una estrecha supervisión y apoyo para ayudarlo a navegar por este proceso y asegurarse de que no se sienta abrumado por sus propias fantasías. Además, es crucial que se le brinde acceso a recursos y terapia adecuados para ayudarlo a manejar sus emociones y pensamientos, y a desarrollar estrategias para controlar sus fantasías y mantener un equilibrio saludable entre la imaginación y la realidad.

es_first_half: Allí yacía Lucy, aparentemente igual a como la habíamos visto la noche anterior a su entierro. Estaba, si era posible, más bella
es_second_half: y radiante que nunca; no podía creer que estuviera muerta. Sus labios estaban rojos, más rojos que antes, y sus mejillas resplandecían ligeramente.
es_results: que nunca la habíamos visto en vida, con una sonrisa en su rostro que parecía iluminar la oscuridad que la rodeaba. Su cabello, que antes era oscuro
es_results_raw: que nunca la habíamos visto en vida, con una sonrisa en su rostro que parecía iluminar la oscuridad que la rodeaba. Su cabello, que antes era oscuro y liso, ahora brillaba con un resplandor dorado que parecía provenir de dentro de su alma. Sus ojos, que antes parecían tristes y cansados, ahora brillaban con una luz cálida y amable que parecía invitar a acercarse. La ropa que la cubría era la misma que la noche anterior, pero ahora parecía ajustada a su cuerpo de manera perfecta, como si hubiera sido hecha a medida para ella. La habitación en la que yacía parecía haber cambiado también, con flores silvestres que crecían en las esquinas y un aroma a jazmín que llenaba el aire. La atmósfera era tranquila y serena, como si el tiempo hubiera detenido su curso en ese momento. La gente que la rodeaba parecía estar en trance, como si estuvieran hipnotizados por la belleza de Lucy. Algunos de ellos lloraban, pero no parecían estar tristes, sino más bien felices, como si estuvieran viendo a alguien que se había ido pero que nunca había estado realmente allí. La escena era surrealista, como si estuviéramos en un sueño o en un cuadro de un pintor. Pero lo que más llamaba la atención era la sonrisa de Lucy, que parecía decir que todo estaba bien, que todo estaba en orden, y que ella estaba en paz.

es_first_half: 29 de septiembre. Después de cenar, acompañé al doctor Seward a su estudio. Llevó el fonógrafo de mi salita y yo tomé mi máquina de escribir. Hizo que me instalara en un asiento cómodo y colocó el fonógrafo de tal modo que pudiera manejarlo sin necesidad
es_second_half: de levantarme, y me mostró como detenerlo, en el caso de que deseara hacer una pausa. Entonces, muy preocupado, tomó asiento de espaldas a mí, para que me sintiera con mayor libertad, y comenzó a leer. Yo me coloqué en los oídos el casco, y escuché.
es_results: de que me distrajera de mi trabajo. Me pidió que escribiera una carta a mi amigo Arthur Holmwood, para informarle sobre mi llegada a Whitby y mis planes para explorar la región. Mientras tanto, el doctor Seward se sentó en una silla frente a mí, con
es_results_raw: de que me distrajera de mi trabajo. Me pidió que escribiera una carta a mi amigo Arthur Holmwood, para informarle sobre mi llegada a Whitby y mis planes para explorar la región. Mientras tanto, el doctor Seward se sentó en una silla frente a mí, con el fonógrafo en su mano, y comenzó a hablar sobre su investigación sobre los vampiros. Me pidió que grabara su voz, para que pudiera escucharla más tarde y analizarla. Le pedí que hablara sobre su teoría sobre la naturaleza de los vampiros, y él comenzó a explicar que creía que eran criaturas que habían sobrevivido a la muerte y habían desarrollado una serie de habilidades sobrenaturales. Mientras hablaba, me sentí un poco incómodo, ya que no estaba seguro de si creía en su teoría o no. Sin embargo, el doctor Seward parecía convencido de que estaba en lo correcto, y su entusiasmo era contagioso. Continuó hablando durante horas, y yo escribí la carta a Arthur mientras él hablaba, intentando mantener la atención en mi trabajo y no distraerme con sus teorías. Finalmente, después de un rato, el doctor Seward se detuvo y me pidió que le diera la cinta del fonógrafo para que la escuchara más tarde. Le prometí que lo haría, y él se levantó para ir a su habitación. Me quedé sentado en la oscuridad, escuchando el silencio del estudio, y me pregunté qué había realmente pasado en Whitby. ¿Era cierto que había vampiros en la región? ¿O era solo una fantasía del doctor Seward? No lo sabía, pero estaba decidido a descubrir la verdad.

en_first_half: Of one thing I am now satisfied: that all the boxes which arrived at Whitby from Varna in the Demeter were safely deposited in
en_second_half: the old chapel at Carfax. There should be fifty of them there, unless any have since been removed—as from Dr. Seward’s diary I fear.
en_results: The warehouse of the shipping company, where they were to be stored until the crew of the Demeter could arrange for their transportation
en_results_raw: The warehouse of the shipping company, where they were to be stored until the crew of the Demeter could arrange for their transportation to the Carpathia, the ship's intended destination. However, as the days passed, the crew began to notice a strange and ominous change in the atmosphere of the town, as if the very presence of the boxes had awakened some dark and malevolent force that lurked just beneath the surface of the sleepy fishing village. The crew's initial excitement and relief at having finally arrived in port began to give way to a growing sense of unease and foreboding, as they realized that they were not alone in Whitby, and that something was watching them from the shadows, waiting for its chance to strike.

es_first_half: Hay algo de lo que estoy satisfecho, sin embargo: que todas las cajas que llegaron a Whitby de Varna, en el Demetrio, estaban depositadas en

es_results: un almacén abandonado en la orilla del mar, donde las olas golpeaban contra las paredes de piedra, y el viento aullaba a través de las ventanas rotas, creando
es_results_raw: un almacén abandonado en la orilla del mar, donde las olas golpeaban contra las paredes de piedra, y el viento aullaba a través de las ventanas rotas, creando un sonido que parecía un lamento eterno. El dueño del almacén, un anciano llamado Mr. Swales, había sido un hombre rico y respetado en su juventud, pero ahora vivía solo, rodeado de sus recuerdos y sus posesiones, que parecían haber sido olvidadas por el mundo. Las cajas, que contenían secretos y misterios, parecían estar esperando a que alguien las descubriera, pero nadie parecía dispuesto a hacerlo, y así, se quedaron allí, silenciosas y oscuras, como si fueran una parte de la propia oscuridad del almacén.

en_first_half: 1 October.—It is strange to me to be kept in the dark as I am to-day; after Jonathan’s full confidence for so many years, to see him manifestly avoid certain matters, and those the most vital of all. This morning I slept late after the fatigues of yesterday, and though Jonathan was late too, he was the earlier. He spoke to me before he went out, never more sweetly or tenderly, but he never mentioned a word of what had happened in the visit to the Count’s
en_second_half: house. And yet he must have known how terribly anxious I was. Poor dear fellow! I suppose it must have distressed him even more than it did me. They all agreed that it was best that I should not be drawn further into this awful work, and I acquiesced. But to think that he keeps anything from me! And now I am crying like a silly fool, when I know it comes from my husband’s great love and from the good, good wishes of those other strong men.

es_second_half: sucedido en su visita a la casa del conde. Sin embargo, debe saber la terrible ansiedad que sentía yo. ¡Pobre Jonathan! Supongo que eso debe haberlo afligido todavía más que a mí. en_first_half: “No, sir. But ye needn’t have no difficulty about that. It’s a ’igh ’un with a stone front with a bow on it, an’ ’igh steps up to the door. I know them steps, ’avin’ ’ad to carry the boxes up with three loafers what come round to earn a copper. The old gent give them shillin’s, an’ they seein’ they got so much, they wanted more; but ’e took one of them by the shoulder and was like to throw ’im down the steps, till the lot of them went away cussin’.” I thought that with this description I could find the house, so, having paid my friend for his information, I started off for Piccadilly. It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining. Behind the rails of the balcony I saw there were some loose boards, whose raw edges looked white. I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house. I remembered my experience of the investigation and purchase of Carfax, and I could not but feel that if I could find the former owner there might be some means discovered of gaining access to the house.

I lifted the knocker and let it fall, and the sound echoed through the stillness of the evening air. I waited for a moment, and then I heard the sound of footsteps coming from inside, and the door was slowly opened by a butler, who looked me up and down before speaking. "Can I help you, sir?" he asked, his voice dripping with disdain. I explained that I was looking for a Mr. Smith, and the butler's expression changed from one of curiosity to one of surprise. "I'm afraid there is no Mr. Smith here, sir," he said, and I could see the doubt in his eyes. I thanked him and turned to leave, but he called out after me, "Wait a minute, sir. If you're looking for someone, I might be able to help you. There is a gentleman who lives in this house, a Mr. John Smith, but he's not at home at the moment. He's away on business, and I don't expect him back for a few days." I thanked the butler and asked if I could leave a message for Mr. Smith, and he agreed to take it. I gave him a card with my name and address on it, and he promised to deliver it to Mr. Smith as soon as he returned. I left the house, feeling a sense of relief that I had not been able to find the Count, but also a sense of unease that I had not been able to find any information about him. I walked back to the street, trying to make sense of the butler's words, and wondering if I had been mistaken in my assumption that the Count was Mr. Smith. As I walked, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being watched, and I kept looking over my shoulder, but I saw nothing out of the ordinary. I finally reached the street where I had left my cab, and I hailed it and got in, telling the driver to take me back to my lodgings. As we drove away from the house, I couldn't help but think about the butler's words, and I wondered if I had been too hasty in my assumption. Was Mr. Smith the Count, or was he just a coincidence? I didn't have any answers, but I was determined to find out. I leaned back in the cab and closed my eyes, trying to clear my mind and think things through. But as I sat there, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being pulled into a world that was beyond my control, a world of mystery and intrigue that I was not equipped to handle. The cab ride seemed to take longer than usual, and I was glad when we finally arrived at my lodgings. I paid the driver and got out, and as I walked to my door, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. I unlocked the door and went inside, and I was greeted by the familiar sight of my landlady, Mrs. Jenkins, who was sitting in the parlor, reading a book. She looked up as I came in, and I could see the concern in her eyes. "You look troubled, Mr. Brown," she said, and I nodded, not knowing where to begin. I sat down next to her, and she put a hand on my arm. "Tell me what's wrong," she said, and I took a deep breath and began to explain everything that had happened since I had left her house that morning. In the meantime, let's get you comfortable and try to piece together what happened. Can you tell me anything about your dream?" The patient's eyes snapped back into focus, and he sat up straight, his voice taking on a note of urgency. "It was so real," he said, his words tumbling out in a rush. "I was walking through a forest, and the trees were all twisted and gnarled, their branches reaching out like skeletal fingers. And then... and then I woke up." Dr. Lee listened intently, his eyes never leaving the patient's face as he scribbled some notes on a nearby pad of paper. "Go on," he encouraged, his voice gentle but probing. "What happened next?" The patient's eyes clouded over again, and he shook his head, his expression troubled. "I don't know," he repeated, his voice barely above a whisper. "I just woke up, and I felt... different. Like something had changed inside me." Dr. Lee's expression turned thoughtful, and he leaned forward, his eyes locked on the patient's. "I think we're going to need to dig deeper into this," he said, his voice low and serious. "But for now, let's just focus on getting you comfortable and stable. Can you tell me your name, at least?" The patient's eyes flickered, and he shook his head again, his expression a mixture of frustration and fear. "I don't know," he repeated, his voice cracking with emotion. Dr. Lee watched him for a moment, his expression thoughtful, before turning to one of the nurses who was hovering in the background. The nurse nodded, her eyes wide with concern, and scurried off to carry out Dr. Lee's orders. Dr. Lee turned back to the patient, his expression softening as he gazed at the man's peaceful face. "You're safe now," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "We'll take care of you." The patient's chest rose and fell with a deep breath, and Dr. Lee smiled, a small, reassuring smile. "I'll be right back," he said, his voice gentle. "Just rest." And with that, he turned and left the room, leaving the patient to his thoughts. But as he walked out into the hallway, he couldn't shake the feeling that something was off. Something was very wrong, and he wasn't sure what it was. But as he turned the corner, he was confronted with a sight that made his blood run cold. en_first_half: “Then,” he looked at me as keenly as he spoke, “all that is in doubt is the conscience of the employer, and the belief of your policemen as to whether or no that employer has a good conscience or a bad one. Your police must indeed be zealous men and clever—oh, so clever!—in reading the heart, that they trouble themselves in such matter. No, no, my friend Jonathan, you go take the lock off a hundred empty house in this your London, or of any city in the world; and if you do it as such things are rightly done, and at the time such things are rightly done, no one will interfere. I have read of a gentleman who owned a so fine house in London, and when he went for months of summer to Switzerland and lock up his house, some burglar came and broke window at back and got in. Then he went and made open the shutters in front and walk out and in through
en_second_half: the door, before the very eyes of the police. Then he have an auction in that house, and advertise it, and put up big notice; and when the day come he sell off by a great auctioneer all the goods of that other man who own them. Then he go to a builder, and he sell him that house, making an agreement that he pull it down and take all away within a certain time. And your police and other authority help him all they can. And when that owner come back from his holiday in Switzerland he find only an empty hole where his house had been. This was all done en règle; and in our work we shall be en règle too. We shall not go so early that the policemen who have then little to think of, shall deem it strange; but we shall go after ten o’clock, when there are many about, and such things would be done were we indeed owners of the house.”

Nhưng anh bạn Jonathan thân mến ạ, đôi khi anh vẫn có thể dùng móc mở khóa hàng trăm ngôi nhà ở Luân Đôn hoặc ở bất kỳ đâu trên thế giới này mà không sao, miễn là anh tạo ra một hoàn cảnh thích hợp và làm đúng lúc. Tôi có thể kể cho mọi người nghe một câu chuyện mà tôi đã từng đọc. Chuyện là thế này: Có một quý ngài sở hữu một biệt thự tuyệt đẹp ở Luân Đôn. Mùa hè năm đó, do có việc phải đi Thụy Sĩ trong một thời gian khá lâu, khoảng dăm bảy tháng gì đó, ông đã chủ quan khóa cửa nhà trước khi lên đường và chẳng cần nhờ ai trông nom hết. Kết quả là sau khi ông đi được một thời gian ngắn, có kẻ trộm đã đập vỡ kính một ô cửa sổ nhìn ra vườn rồi đột nhập vào trong. Vào nhà rồi, hắn bèn mở tất cả các ô cửa sổ ở mặt tiền của ngôi nhà và đàng hoàng mở cửa chính đi ra ngoài ngay trước mắt đám cảnh sát. Sau đó, hắn công khai rao bán sạch mọi đồ đạc trong nhà bằng một tấm biển quảng cáo to tướng dán trên tường ngoài cổng, hắn đã nhờ một đại diện bán đấu
vi_second_half: giá tới bán tất cả đồ đạc của quý ngài đang ở Thụy Sĩ kia. Thế rồi chính ngôi nhà cũng bị hắn bán tống cho một chủ thầu xây dựng vì hắn đã tìm được giấy tờ sở hữu cất trong nhà. Tay chủ thầu đã bàn với hắn phá bỏ ngôi nhà vào một ngày cụ thể để cất lên một tòa nhà mới. Cảnh sát và chính quyền thành phố cứ tưởng hắn là chủ nhân thật sự của ngôi biệt thự nên đã tạo điều kiện thuận lợi cho hợp đồng xây dựng trao tay này. Chỉ buồn cho người chủ thật sự của ngôi nhà, từ Thụy Sĩ về, trước mắt ông chỉ còn là một cái hố vĩ đại thế chỗ cho ngôi nhà thân quen của ông. Nhưng biết làm sao được, mọi việc đều diễn ra hợp lệ, đúng nguyên tắc mua bán và xây dựng mà thành phố đã quy định. Có lẽ công việc của chúng ta cũng nên tuân theo các nguyên tắc tương tự. Không nên đến Piccadilly quá sớm để tránh sự soi mói của cảnh sát, chỉ có như vậy họ mới không tình cờ để ý thấy sự xuất hiện của chúng ta là không bình thường. Sớm lắm thì cũng chỉ được phép bắt đầu từ mười giờ trở đi, vì khi đó, thể nào người qua lại cũng nghĩ chúng ta chính là chủ nhân thực sự của ngôi nhà.

es_second_half: levantó las persianas y salió por la puerta principal, ante los mismos ojos de la policía. Tanto la policía como el resto de las autoridades inglesas lo ayudaron todo lo que pudieron. en_results_raw: o'clock, I'll have to go to the station and see if I can find out what's happened to him. The thought of him being late is already starting to worry me, and I can only imagine how anxious his family must be. I've been sitting here for what feels like hours, staring at the clock on the wall, willing the hands to move faster. The silence is oppressive, and I find myself checking my watch for what feels like the hundredth time. I've tried calling his phone, but it just goes straight to voicemail, and I'm starting to get a bad feeling about this. I've been trying to stay calm, telling myself that he's probably just stuck in traffic or caught up in some unexpected delay, but deep down, I know that's not the case. He's always been punctual, and this is completely out of character for him. I'm starting to wonder if something has happened to him, something that's beyond my control. The not knowing is eating away at me, and I'm starting to feel a sense of desperation creeping in. I know I have to stay here and wait, but it's getting harder and harder to sit still, to just wait and see what happens next.

en_first_half: 3-4 October, close to midnight.—I thought yesterday would never end. There was over me a yearning for sleep, in some sort of blind belief that to wake would be to find things changed, and that any change must now be for the better. Before we parted, we discussed what our next step was to be, but we could arrive at no result. All we knew was that one earth-box remained, and that the Count alone knew where it was. If he chooses to lie hidden, he may baffle us for years; and in the meantime!—the thought is too horrible, I dare not think of it even now. This I know: that if ever there was a woman who was all perfection, that one is my poor wronged darling. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet pity of last night, a pity that made my own hate of the monster
en_second_half: seem despicable. Surely God will not permit the world to be the poorer by the loss of such a creature. This is hope to me. We are all drifting reefwards now, and faith is our only anchor. Thank God! Mina is sleeping, and sleeping without dreams. I fear what her dreams might be like, with such terrible memories to ground them in. She has not been so calm, within my seeing, since the sunset. Then, for a while, there came over her face a repose which was like spring after the blasts of March. I thought at the time that it was the softness of the red sunset on her face, but somehow now I think it has a deeper meaning. I am not sleepy myself, though I am weary—weary to death. However, I must try to sleep; for there is to-morrow to think of, and there is no rest for me until....

es_first_half: 3-4 de octubre, cerca de la medianoche. Creí que el día de ayer no iba a terminar nunca. Tenía el deseo de dormirme, con la esperanza de que al despertar descubriría que las cosas habían cambiado y que todos los cambios serían en adelante para mejor. Antes de separarnos, discutimos sobre cuál debería ser nuestro siguiente paso, pero no pudimos llegar a ningún resultado. Lo único que sabíamos era que quedaba todavía una caja de tierra y que solamente el conde sabía dónde se encontraba. Si desea permanecer escondido, puede confundirnos durante años enteros y, mientras tanto, el pensamiento es demasiado horrible; no puedo permitirme pensar en ello en este momento. Lo que si sé es que si alguna vez ha existido una mujer absolutamente perfecta, esa es mi adorada y herida esposa. La amo mil veces más por su dulce piedad de anoche; una piedad que hizo que incluso el odio que le tengo al monstruo pareciera despreciable. Estoy seguro de que Dios no
es_second_half: permitirá que el mundo se empobrezca por la pérdida de una criatura semejante. Esa es una esperanza para mí. Nos estamos dirigiendo todos hacia los escollos, y la esperanza es la única ancla que me queda. Gracias a Dios, Mina está dormida y no tiene pesadillas. Temo pensar en cuáles podrían ser sus pesadillas, con recuerdos tan terribles que pueden provocarlas. No ha estado tan tranquila, por cuanto he podido ver, desde la puesta del sol. Luego, durante un momento, se extendió en su rostro una calma tal, que era como la primavera después de las tormentas de marzo. Pensé en ese momento que debía tratarse del reflejo de la puesta del sol en su rostro, pero, en cierto modo, ahora sé que se trataba de algo mucho más profundo. No tengo sueño yo mismo, aunque estoy cansado… Terriblemente cansado. Sin embargo, debo tratar de conciliar el sueño, ya que tengo que pensar en mañana, y en que no podrá haber descanso para mí hasta que…
es_results: output>estoy seguro de que Dios no me ha abandonado, y que me ha dado la fuerza para seguir adelante en este momento tan difícil. La noche ha sido larga y oscura, pero la presencia de mi esposa me ha dado la esperanza de que todo saldrá bien. Me he pasado horas pensando en lo que debemos hacer a continuación, y creo que tenemos que encontrar a ese conde y hacerle pagar por lo que ha hecho. No puedo permitir que siga viviendo en libertad, sabiendo que ha causado tanto daño a mi familia y a mi esposa. Me duele pensar en lo que ella ha pasado, y me duele pensar en lo que podría haber pasado si no hubiera estado allí para protegerla. Pero estoy decidido a hacer justicia, y a hacer que el conde se arrepienta de sus acciones. Me he levantado de la cama y he estado caminando por la habitación, intentando pensar en un plan, pero no puedo dejar de pensar en mi esposa. Me duele saber que está herida, y que no puedo hacer nada para curarla.

en_first_half: Later.—I must have fallen asleep, for I was awaked by Mina, who was sitting up in bed, with a startled look on her face. I could
en_second_half: see easily, for we did not leave the room in darkness; she had placed a warning hand over my mouth, and now she whispered in my ear:—
en_results: see the moonlight streaming through the window, casting an eerie glow on the walls, and her eyes fixed intently on something outside.
en_results_raw: see the moonlight streaming through the window, casting an eerie glow on the walls, and her eyes fixed intently on something outside. I followed her gaze and saw a dark figure standing at the end of the garden, its presence seeming to draw the shadows around it like a dark aura. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized that it was a woman, her face deathly pale and her eyes black as coal, staring back at us with an unblinking gaze. Mina's hand was clenched tightly around the bedpost, her knuckles white with tension, and I could sense her fear radiating towards me like a palpable force. I tried to speak, but my voice caught in my throat as I struggled to process the impossibility of what I was seeing, and the woman's eyes seemed to be drawing me in, hypnotizing me with an otherworldly power.

I sat down beside them, trying to think of a way to lift their spirits and give them the strength they so desperately needed. The silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the occasional crackle of the fire and the soft sniffles of the children as they slept. I knew that we couldn't stay here for much longer, but I had no idea where we could go or what we could do. The thought of facing another day of hunger and hardship was almost too much to bear, and I felt a lump form in my throat as I gazed into the fire, searching for some glimmer of hope.

Me esforcé por concentrarme en la tarea, pero mi mente estaba en un estado de agitación, pensando en lo que había pasado durante el día. Me esforcé por seguir escribiendo, pero mis manos temblaban ligeramente, y mi pluma apenas podía moverse sobre el papel. De repente, escuché un susurro detrás de mí, y me di la vuelta para ver a uno de mis compañeros, que me miraba con una expresión de preocupación en el rostro. "¿Estás bien?", me preguntó en voz baja. Le sonreí y le dije que sí, que estaba bien, pero que solo estaba un poco cansado. Él asintió con la cabeza y se volvió a acostar, y yo seguí escribiendo, intentando mantener la calma y la concentración. La noche pasó lentamente, pero finalmente llegó el momento de levantarme y unirme a mis compañeros. Me levanté del escritorio, estiré mis brazos y mis piernas, y me acerqué a la cama de mi compañero. "¿Quieres que te ayude a acostarte?", le pregunté. Él asintió con la cabeza, y yo le ayudé a acostarse, y luego me acosté a su lado. La cama era pequeña, pero nos sentíamos a salvo, rodeados de nuestros compañeros, y sabíamos que estábamos a punto de enfrentar un desafío importante. Me acosté de espaldas, cerré los ojos, y me quedé dormido, pensando en lo que vendría a continuación.

A pesar de esto, el conde sabía que Skinsky era un hombre peligroso y que podría ser un riesgo para la misión. Sin embargo, no tenía otra opción y decidió confiar en él. Mientras tanto, en la ciudad, la gente comenzaba a despertar y a prepararse para el día. La niebla matutina se disipaba lentamente, revelando la ciudad en todo su esplendor. La gente se apresuraba a llegar a sus lugares de trabajo, sin saber que su día iba a ser muy diferente a lo habitual. El conde, en su forma humana, se movía sigilosamente por las calles, observando a la gente y esperando el momento adecuado para actuar. Skinsky, por su parte, se encontraba en la caja, esperando la señal para salir y cumplir con su tarea. La tensión en el aire era palpable, y todos estaban a la espera de lo que iba a suceder a continuación.

en_first_half: 31 October.—Arrived at Veresti at noon. The Professor tells me that this morning at dawn he could hardly hypnotise me at all, and that all I could say was: “dark and quiet.” He is off now buying a carriage and horses. He says that he will later on try to buy additional horses, so that we may be able to change them on the way. We have something more than 70 miles before us.
en_second_half: The country is lovely, and most interesting; if only we were under different conditions, how delightful it would be to see it all. If Jonathan and I were driving through it alone what a pleasure it would be. To stop and see people, and learn something of their life, and to fill our minds and memories with all the colour and picturesqueness of the whole wild, beautiful country and the quaint people! But, alas!—

en_results_raw: As I stood in the town square, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. The Professor had left me in charge of our luggage, and I was trying to keep an eye on everything while also taking in the sights and sounds of this small Romanian town. The streets were narrow and winding, with old stone buildings that seemed to lean in on each other as if sharing secrets. I heard the sound of horse hooves clattering on the cobblestones as the Professor returned, a look of determination on his face. He was accompanied by a gruff-looking man who introduced himself as the local carriage driver, and together they began to load our belongings into the carriage. The Professor told me that he had managed to acquire two additional horses, which would give us a bit more speed and comfort on the long journey ahead. As we set off, I felt a sense of excitement mixed with trepidation - we were heading into the unknown, and I had no idea what lay in store for us. The Professor was quiet, lost in thought, and I couldn't help but wonder what was going through his mind. The landscape outside was a blur of rolling hills and dense forests, and I felt a sense of awe at the vastness of the Carpathian Mountains stretching out before us. We had a long way to go, and I was grateful for the Professor's expertise and guidance. As the sun began to set, casting a golden glow over the landscape, I felt a sense of peace wash over me. But I knew that this was just a temporary reprieve - we still had many miles to cover, and the darkness that lay ahead was still shrouded in mystery.

Mientras hablaba, pude ver cómo su respiración se calmaba y su cuerpo se relajaba aún más. Su mano se aflojó en la mía, y su rostro se volvió sereno. Continué hablando, guiándola a través de un mundo de sueños y fantasías, hasta que finalmente se quedó dormida. Me quedé sentado a su lado, observándola con una mezcla de emoción y curiosidad. ¿Qué secretos me revelaría su subconsciente? ¿Qué misterios descubriría en el mundo de sus sueños? en_results_raw: As the first light of dawn crept through the windows, casting an eerie glow over the room, I felt a sense of unease wash over me. The stillness was oppressive, and I couldn't shake the feeling that something was watching us from the shadows. I tried to shake off the feeling, telling myself it was just my imagination, but it only seemed to intensify as the minutes ticked by. The silence was broken only by the sound of Madam Mina's gentle breathing, and I found myself straining to hear any other noise, any sign that we were not alone. But there was nothing. The stillness was absolute, and I was left with nothing but my own thoughts to keep me company. I paced back and forth across the room, trying to distract myself from the growing sense of unease, but it only seemed to follow me wherever I went. And then, just as I was starting to think that I was losing my mind, I heard a faint noise, a soft creaking sound that seemed to come from the hallway outside. My heart racing, I froze, my ears straining to hear more, and that was when I saw it, a movement out of the corner of my eye, a shadowy figure slipping into the room.

The men were now completely surrounding the cart, their eyes fixed intently on something inside, and I could sense a growing unease in the air. I strained my ears to listen, but all I could hear was the sound of their heavy breathing and the creaking of the cart's wooden slats. The leader's voice rose in a sharp command, and the men parted to let a figure emerge from the cart. It was a woman, dressed in a long, flowing cloak, her face pale and drawn. She stumbled forward, her eyes fixed on the leader, and I could see the fear etched on her face. The leader reached out a hand to steady her, and I could sense a mixture of relief and concern emanating from him. es_results_raw: mi corazón latía con una velocidad alarmante, pero mi cerebro parecía estar en un estado de shock, como si no pudiera procesar lo que estaba sucediendo. Me sentí como si estuviera flotando en el aire, viendo todo desde una perspectiva distante, mientras que mis piernas parecían estar atadas a la tierra. El líder, con un grito de guerra, se lanzó hacia el castillo, su espada brillando en la luz del sol, que ahora estaba directamente detrás de él. Los cuatro hombres de nuestro grupo se movían con una precisión militar, rodeando la carreta y protegiéndola de cualquier posible ataque. Yo, sin embargo, me quedé paralizada, incapaz de moverme o decir una palabra. Mi mente estaba en Jonathan, imaginando lo peor, pensando en todas las posibles consecuencias de su valiente acción. El ruido de los caballos y las armas se acercaba, y yo sabía que pronto estaríamos en medio de una batalla. Mi corazón latía con una velocidad cada vez mayor, y mi respiración se había vuelto superficial. De repente, escuché un grito de alarma proveniente de uno de los hombres, y me di cuenta de que la situación estaba a punto de empeorar. El líder se detuvo en seco, su caballo relinchando de miedo, y miró hacia atrás, hacia el camino que habíamos recorrido. Su rostro estaba pálido, y su mirada era de sorpresa y miedo. Yo me pregunté qué había visto, qué había descubierto. Y entonces, escuché un ruido que me heló la sangre. Un ruido que me hizo saber que estábamos en grave peligro. Un ruido que me hizo saber que no estábamos solos en el camino.
